results.title: Will you hold my hand?
results.brief_description: Pegg Utting was one of the first women to join the newly formed WAAAF in 1941. Her son would later join up to serve in Vietnam aged 17. Like so many others he struggled to fit in when he returned. After many years, he was finally invited to March with the RSL and it was Peg’s loving support that got him through this.
results.description: Pegg Utting was one of the first women to join the newly formed WAAAF in 1941. Her son would later join up to serve in Vietnam aged 17. Like so many others he struggled to fit in when he returned. After many years, he was finally invited to March with the RSL and it was Peg’s loving support that got him through this.

results.title: Why did we fight?: the experience of a Vietnamese Veteran
results.brief_description: Hung and his family were originally from North Vietnam but after fleeing as a child to the South, he would follow in this father’s footsteps and join the army to fight for freedom. After being captured and spending years in re-education camps, his family finally decided to flee to Australia to start a new life.

results.title: Walk - Walk - Walk
results.brief_description: In 1966 Paul was playing in a band, ‘The Castaways’, the next minute he was conscripted to service in Vietnam. When Paul arrived in Vietnam he was told, “You’re in the infantry now, you will walk, and walk, and walk some more. You had to keep on moving, that was how you got through.”
results.description: In 1966 Paul was playing in a band, ‘The Castaways’, the next minute he was conscripted to service in Vietnam. When Paul arrived in Vietnam he was told, “You’re in the infantry now, you will walk, and walk, and walk some more. You had to keep on moving, that was how you got through.”

When Paul arrived in Vietnam he was told, “You’re in the infantry now, you will walk, and walk, and walk some more. You had to keep on moving, that was how you got through.”

results.title: The Effects of war never change
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Jeff Freeman and ACMI
results.brief_description: Jeff only served 2 years in the army in South Vietnam. It was extremely hard to return to normal life and keep an office job after one year in the jungle. The reaction to Vietnam veterans in Australia only made it harder for him to adjust back into a normal life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Jeff Freeman and ACMI

results.title: Remembering 1945
results.brief_description: Jude remembers her childhood and realises so much of her young life involved war and trauma. Visiting her father in the repatriation hospital she saw first-hand the effects of WWII on those that returned. Most of the men in her family went to WWII and she recalls how the family never recovered from the loss of one cousin at the hands of the Japanese as a POW.
results.description: Jude remembers her childhood and realises so much of her young life involved war and trauma. Visiting her father in the repatriation hospital she saw first-hand the effects of WWII on those that returned. Most of the men in her family went to WWII and she recalls how the family never recovered from the loss of one cousin at the hands of the Japanese as a POW.

Visiting her father in the repatriation hospital she saw first-hand the effects of WWII on those that returned. results.title: A Naive country kid
results.brief_description:
At 17 Greg joined the air force and his role would be to give the aircraft the best chance of surviving a crash. Two years after joining up, Greg was sent to Thailand and one particular aircraft rescue would change his outlook on life forever.
Called out to an aircraft crash to help the Americans contain a huge fire, the Aussies were unaware where the aircraft had come from. After the flames were put out, Greg would realise this was a Thai plane that he had flown on many times. The memory of this day would stay with him all his life.

results.title: I've been everywhere
results.creator_credit: Rob Flisher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Robert Flisher was excited to leave Australia and see the world as it was his childhood dream to join the Navy. Flisher opens up about his experiences with the Navy and talks about some of the exciting places he visited during his service.

results.title: A Life on the farm
results.creator_credit: Oz Sanderson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Oz Sanderson grew up on his farm with his two brothers during the Great Depression. His dad signed a consent form for him to join the army. While Oz was determined to serve as a pilot, the farm was always in his heart and he was more than happy to return to it after the war ended.

results.title: Survivor
results.creator_credit: Oz Phillips, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: At 18, Oswald enlisted in the Army through the Scotch College Cadet Force. He served in Darwin for two and a half years, surviving 76 raids, before training for inventory and being sent to Borneo to engage the Japanese. He can only recall the experience with “fear, fright and exhilaration”. Declared unfit for military service, he took some time to feel better again before marrying in 1950.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oz Phillips, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

He can only recall the experience with “fear, fright and exhilaration”. Declared unfit for military service, he took some time to feel better again before marrying in 1950.

results.title: The St Arnaud boys
results.creator_credit: Norm Michael, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Norm started his life in the Army with six other local boys from his local area. He really enjoyed the mateship and sense of community he shared with them, and reminisces on the good times they had over the years. The mateship still lives on today when Norm catches up with them back in their home town, St Arnaud.
